definitions.definition: the dried leaves (called tea leaves) of the tea bush

examples.text: a packet of tea
I spooned the tea into the pot.
a blend of different teas *(= types of tea)*

definitions.definition: a hot drink made by pouring boiling water onto tea leaves. It may be drunk with milk or lemon and/or sugar added.

examples.text: a **cup of tea**
A pot of tea for two, please.
**iced tea**
Would you like tea or coffee?
I don't drink tea.
Do you take sugar in your tea?
She sipped her hot tea slowly.
Allow the tea to cool before you drink it.
I'll bring you a cup of tea in a few minutes.
I'll have tea—white, no sugar, please.
I'll make you some tea.
John rushed around dispensing tea and cakes to everyone.
There's some fresh tea in the pot.
You haven't let the tea brew long enough.
All rooms have tea-making facilities.
The hospital tea bar is run by volunteers.
an authentic Japanese tea house
Two teas, please.

definitions.definition: a hot drink made by pouring boiling water onto the leaves of other plants

examples.text: camomile/mint/herbal tea

definitions.definition: the name used by some people in the UK for the cooked meal eaten in the evening, especially when it is eaten early in the evening

examples.text: You can have your tea as soon as you come home from school.

definitions.definition: a light meal eaten in the afternoon or early evening, usually with sandwiches and/or biscuits and cakes and with tea to drink

examples.text: Would you like to come to tea on Sunday?
I cleared away the tea things.

definitions.definition: not what somebody likes or is interested in

examples.text: An evening at the opera isn't everyone's cup of tea.
He's nice enough but not really my cup of tea.

definitions.definition: not even for a great reward

examples.text: I wouldn't do your job. Not for all the tea in China!

definitions.definition: to tell somebody something that should be kept secret or private

examples.text: We don't want to spill the beans yet.
She made the mistake of spilling the tea on her sister's love life.

wordOrigin: mid 17th cent.: probably via Malay from Chinese (Min dialect) te; related to Mandarin chá. Compare with char (noun - sense 2).
